column1: Green Bay () is a city in the U.S. state of Wisconsin. The county seat of Brown County
column2: it is at the head of Green Bay (known locally as "the bay of Green Bay")
column3: a sub-basin of Lake Michigan
column4: at the mouth of the Fox River. It is 581 feet (177 m) above sea level and 112 miles (180 km) north of Milwaukee. The population was 104
column5: 057 at the 2010 census. Green Bay is the third-largest city in the state of Wisconsin
column6: after Milwaukee and Madison
column7: and the third-largest city on Lake Michigan's west shore
column8: after Chicago and Milwaukee. Green Bay is home to the National Football League's Green Bay Packers.

column1: === From the trading post La Baie des Puants to the town La Baie verte ===
Nicolet founded a small trading post here in 1634
column2: originally named La Baye or La Baie des Puants (French for "the Bay of Stinking Waters"). Nicolet's settlement was one of the oldest European permanent settlements in America.When Nicolet arrived in the Green Bay area
column3: he encountered the Menominee
column4: as this was their territory. He also met the Ho-Chunk
column6: a people who spoke a Sioux language. The Winnebago hunted
column7: fished
column12: which they had incorporated as a dietary staple
column13: grew in abundance along the riverbanks. They regularly harvested and cooked this

column16: and edible roots of the woods. The tribe had clearly distinguished gender roles. The men typically hunted and fished for food
column17: and the women processed game and other foods in cooking. They prepared and made clothing from the furs as well as using other parts of animals for tools
column19: etc. Women also had a role in the political process

column1: A few months after Nicolet returned to Quebec
column2: Champlain died. His death halted other journeys to La Baie Verte (French for "The Green Bay"). PÃ¨re Claude Allouez sent Nicolas Perrot to La Baie. After this
column3: the French avoided the area for some decades
column4: because of the intensity of First Nations and European conflicts in the east. In 1671
column5: a Jesuit Mission was set up in the area. A fort was added in 1717 and gradually associated development took place. The town was incorporated in 1754.  As Great Britain took control of French areas during the Seven Years' War
column6: known as the French and Indian War in some areas of North America
column7: this town came under British control in 1761. The French ceded their North American lands East of the Mississippi River to the British following defeat in 1763.

column1: The first permanent French settlers were Charles de Langlade and his family from Canada
column2: who moved to Green Bay in 1765
column3: becoming the first European-American settlers in today's Wisconsin. Langlade
column4: called the "Founder and Father of Wisconsin"
column5: was an Ottawa war chief with a French father. He is credited with planning the ambush of British General Braddock and George Washington in the French and Indian War. The Grignons
column6: Porliers and Lawes
column7: who followed
column8: brought Canadian-French culture with them. Colorful "jack-knife Judge" Reaume dispensed British justice in the territory. These early French settlers set the tone for many who followed.

column1: The British gradually took over Wisconsin during the French and Indian War
column2: taking control of Green Bay in 1761 and gaining control of all of Wisconsin in 1763. Like the French
column3: the British were interested in little but the fur trade. In 1791
column4: two free African Americans set up a fur trading post among the Menominee at present day Marinette. The first permanent settlers
column6: some Anglo-New Englanders and a few African American freedmen
column7: arrived in Wisconsin while it was under British control. Charles Michel de Langlade is generally recognized as the first settler
column8: establishing a trading post at Green Bay in 1745
column9: and moving there permanently in 1764. Settlement began at Prairie du Chien around 1781.  The French residents at the trading post in what is now Green Bay
column10: referred to the town as "La Bey"
column11: however British fur traders referred to it as "Green Bay"
column12: because the water and the shore assumed green tints in early spring.  The old French title was gradually dropped
column13: and the British name of "Green Bay" stuck.  The region coming under British rule had virtually no adverse effect on the French residents as the British needed the cooperation of the French fur traders and the French fur traders needed the goodwill of the British.  During the French occupation of the region licenses for fur trading had been issued scarcely and only to select groups of traders
column15: in an effort to make as much money as possible from the region
column16: issued licenses for fur trading freely
column17: both to British and French residents.  The fur trade in what is now Wisconsin reached its height under British rule
column18: and the first self-sustaining farms in the state were established as well.  From 1763 to 1780
column19: Green Bay was a prosperous community which produced its own foodstuff
column20: built graceful cottages and held dances and festivities.

column1: The Green Bay area was still under British control until the 1783 treaty formally ended the American Revolutionary War. Following the War of 1812
column2: which in part was over disputes related to the border with Canada
column3: the United States built Fort Howard on the Fox River in 1816 to protect its northern border. Doty

column6: Baird and Martin were among the many British-American settlers whose numbers pushed French culture into the background.  As British settlers in the area came to outnumber the French
column7: they referred to the town as "Green Bay" (from the French: Baie Verte).

column1: The Erie Canal was completed in 1825
column2: linking New England with the Great Lakes.  This led to the advance of Green Bay as a trading center.  The end of the Black Hawk War in 1832 also gave impetus to settlement of the region.  Most of the settlers were farmers from New England who began using the Erie Canal to pour into Wisconsin.  As more and more New England settlers arrived
column3: Green Bay developed into a trading center for this population.

column1: By 1850 the town had a population of 1
column2: 923. The town was incorporated as the city of Green Bay in 1854. The Green Bay Area Public School District was founded in 1856. Throughout the 1850s
column3: word spread of America's cheap land and good soil
column4: bringing in an influx of Belgian people
column6: Scandinavian
column7: Irish and Dutch immigrants
column8: each adding to the culture. The greatest concentration of newcomers came from Belgium. They cleared the land to farm and build their homes.The railroad arrived in the 1860s. Chicago and Northwestern Railroad companies were formed
column9: which allowed people and products to travel all over the state
column10: increasing business and trade opportunities. The area was able to grow and enrich itself with the use of the river and the plentiful timber resources. This led to the paper industry becoming the major employer in Green Bay
column11: and opened up the port for international trade.Large numbers of Belgians immigrated to Green Bay in the thirty-year period between 1880 and 1910.  Significant numbers of English immigrants
column12: many having lived first in Canada
column13: also moved to Green Bay during this period
column14: usually arriving as large families. There was also a small Dutch community in Green Bay at this time. Green Bay had a larger portion of first generation immigrants from France than any other city in Wisconsin at this time as well.In 1934

column1: Green Bay is governed by a mayor and a city council.  The mayor is elected in a citywide vote. The city council consists of 12 members each elected from districts.

column1: From 1896 to 1993 the city was the headquarters of the Green Bay and Western Railroad. In 1993
column2: the line was purchased by the Wisconsin Central. In 2001
column3: the WC was merged into the Canadian National Railway. The Chicago and North Western Railway also served Green Bay and its depot still stands. Green Bay was last served with a regular passenger train
column4: the CNW's Peninsula 400
column5: in 1971. The CNW sold its trackage from Green Bay south to Sheboygan in 1987 to the Fox River Valley Railroad
column6: which became part of the WC in 1993. Green Bay also saw passenger service from the Milwaukee Road's Chippewa-Hiawatha
column7: which ran from Chicago into the upper peninsula of Michigan. Green Bay is also served by the Escanaba and Lake Superior Railroad.

The Brown County Library (BCL) Central Branch is located in downtown Green Bay and has served as the county public library since 1968. The Central Branch is the headquarters for the BCL system
column2: which encompasses all public libraries in Brown County
column3: including eight branch libraries and a bookmobile that regularly visits locations throughout the county. In 1994
column4: the Brown County Library was named Wisconsin Library of the Year.

St. Mary of the Angels Church and Monastery is also located in the city.

Green Bay is known as the "Toilet Paper Capital of the World" because of the prevalence of the paper industry in the city. Northern Paper Company
column2: Fort Howard Paper Company
column3: and Hoberg Paper Company were among Green Bay's first paper companies. Northern Paper Company offered the first splinter-free toilet paper in the early 1930s. The presence of the paper industry helped Green Bay avoid the worst effects of the Great Depression. Today
column4: major paper producers include Georgia-Pacific
column6: and Steen-Macek Paper Company.Among the earliest packing companies in Green Bay were Acme Packing Company and Indian Packing Company
column7: the namesake of the Green Bay Packers. Today
column8: major meatpackers in the city include JBS S.A. (formerly Packerland Packing) and American Foods Group.
